summary: An email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney expressing urgency about indicting Jeffrey Epstein before a May vacation, discussing the assignment of another AUSA from Miami or Fort Pierce, and noting concerns about travel logistics.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: Author of the email, urgently seeking to indict Jeffrey Epstein before a May vacation and discussing assignment of another AUSA.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the potential indictment discussed in the email.

connections.description: The AUSA is working to indict Epstein, indicating a prosecutor-target relationship.

events.title: Urgent Email About Epstein Indictment
events.description: An AUSA sends an email stressing the need to get an answer about indicting Jeffrey Epstein that day, or it may be delayed until after a 3-week vacation in May.

events.title: AUSA's Planned Vacation
events.description: The AUSA mentions a planned 3-week vacation in May, which creates urgency in the Epstein indictment timeline.

locations: 500 S. Australian Ave, Suite 400 West Palm Beach, FL 33401
keyFacts: An Assistant U.S. Attorney expressed urgency on April 21, 2008, about indicting Jeffrey Epstein, needing an answer that day to avoid delay.
The AUSA was concerned that without immediate action, the indictment might be postponed until after a 3-week vacation in May.
The email discusses assigning another AUSA, with preferences for someone from Miami or Fort Pierce, and mentions travel concerns.
The correspondence reveals prosecutorial pressure and timeline constraints in the early stages of the Epstein case.
